user.biography: National Geographic Explorer and NY Times photographer, creating an aerial perspective on climate change and global food supply @feedtheplanet

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by George Steinmetz on July 31, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text: First light on Isla Pabellon, a volcanic islet at 12,800 ft. in the Salar de Uyuni.  The island has been terraced with ancient shore lines from wetter times when the Salar was a salt lake trapped between to branches of the Andes. At that time, the islet had a shape similar to a coral atoll.  From #DesertAirBook, autographed copies available via link in IG bio.

node.text: Migrating mega-dunes of Sossusvlei, Namibia.  The Namib is one of the oldest deserts in the world, as indicated by the color of the sand on the inland side of the dune field. The beach sand of this coastal desert starts out white, but after some 50 million years of sun, wind, and morning dew, the sand grains have traveled some 40 miles inland and taken on a deep orange hue.  From my first book, #AfricanAirBook, autographed copies available via link in IG bio

node.text: Fishermen in the Colorado River Delta of Mexico must battle 30 ft. tides during full moon. This was once one of the richest fisheries in North America, but has been greatly degraded by water diversions and over-fishing. Tremendous spring floods once inundated the delta annually, but an intensive network of dams and irrigation projects in the 20th century turned this once fertile area into almost sterile sand flat.

node.text:
Fishermen off-loading their catch through the surf in Nouakchott, Mauritania. 
The official catch in Mauritania is 900,000 tons, but reconstructed catch estimates are more than 2M tons/year. This pelagic fishery has been migrating northward some 5° (300NM) every 10 years for the past few decades due to changing sea temperatures, and increased fishing pressure.

node.text: Transplanting Del Monte Gold pineapples on a  plantation near Buenos Aires, Costa Rica.  Pineapples are somewhat primitive plants that can transplanted by placing base of their spikey crowns in the soil to start a new plant.  Del Monte has 230 sq mi of of pineapple, banana, and melons in Costa Rica, and keeps 26% of it in a wild or re-wilded state, providing biological corridors for wildlife and buffer zone for watersheds.

Photo by George Steinmetz in Buenos Aires, Alajuela, Costa Rica. May be an image of 1 person, outdoors and text that says '©2021 George Steinmetz'.

node.text: Harvesting pineapples on a plantation in the foothills of Costa Rica.  The Del Monte Gold variety was developed here 25 years ago, and has become the dominant commercial variety worldwide, tripling U.S. pineapple consumption over the past two decades, due to its sweet, less acidic flavor.  Each fruit is picked by a hand ($40/day for a 10 hour shift), before being chilled for shipment by containerized boat to markets in N. America, Europe, and the Middle East.  Due to its unique geography, these foothill plantations are only a few hours from both Pacific and Caribbean ports, allowing Costa Rica to provide almost half of the global supply of pineapples.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by George Steinmetz on July 25, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text: Rain brought a pause to the wheat and hay harvest last week on the plateau overlooking The Badlands of South Dakota.  Most of the farming on these thin soils is done with a no-till  technique as the crop stubble prevents soil loss from erosion, and herbicides are used for weed control.  Crops are rotated regularly between hay, wheat, and sometimes corn.  A recent study indicated that as much as 1/3 of the U.S. cornbelt has undergone significant erosion of topsoil over the past century, leading to increasing adoption of no-till techniques.

node.text: Doug Hellinger, the third generation to farm this land, using a boom sprayer last week to keep down weeds as he drives past his grandmother’s abandoned barn near Shelby, Montana.  His grandparents came here in 1909, when the Homestead Act offered the deed to 320 acres for those who farmed the land for 5 years.  At that time there were 72 families on every 36 square miles.  Now there are only 8 people left in that same rural district, and many farms are over 10,000 acres.  Farming on the semi-arid plains of Northern Montana has become increasingly difficult and mechanized.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by George Steinmetz on July 24, 2021. May be an image of outdoors.
Photo by George Steinmetz on July 24, 2021. May be an image of outdoors.
Photo by George Steinmetz on July 23, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text: Spring wheat is planted in stripes on the semi-arid plains of Northern Montana.  The area is too dry for an annual crop, so stripes are left fallow in alternating years to save moisture for the subsequent crop.  The stripes are separated by trees planted perpendicular to the wind to prevent wind erosion. Virtually all of the farmers I met here last week have now adopted a no-till “chem-fallow’ system, where they leave the stripes of wheat stubble in the ground to prevent wind erosion, and spray it with paraquat to kill the weeds and save the moisture for the alternate year. Some expressed uncertainty on the wisdom of the chem-fallow process, as the chemicals are expensive, and the long-term effect on both soil and their own health are unknown.

node.text:
Photo by @amivitale. I am thrilled to share the new short film "Shaba" by my good friend Ami Vitale. The film tells the extraordinary story of Reteti Elephant Sanctuary, the first community-owned elephant sanctuary in Africa.  The film is now online and your ticket sales will go directly to support the elephants and their incredible keepers. It is available on-demand from today until August 31. Visit shabafilm.org or click on the link in my profile to watch today.
 
@r.e.s.c.u.e @sararafoundation @conservationorg @kenyawildlifeservice @nrt_kenya @tusk_org @sandiegozoo @thephotosociety @passionplanet #shabafilm #shaba #retetielephants  #DontLetThemDisappear #elephants #saveelephants #stoppoaching #kenya #natureisspeaking #conservation

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by George Steinmetz on July 19, 2021. May be an image of standing.

node.text:
Al Ain Dairy, in Abu Dhabi, the world’s first commercial dairy for camel milk, which produces full cream camel milk and camel milk powder for the Gulf market.  Their 1,500 camels need three times as many years as cows to start producing milk, and three times as long between births, making their Camelait a prized commodity at 3x the price.  Unlike Al Ain’s herd of Holsteins, the dromedaries aren’t fussy feeders, or need air conditioning in the desert heat. 

If you want to hear more about my @FeedThePlanet project, I will be on a live stream interview with @AJStream today at 4:30 EDT.

location.name: Al Ain City, Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

node.text: My wingman Alain Arnoux, as we shared an epic flight over the Dasht-e Kavir, Iran. This inhospitable basin is filled with the tops of ancient salt deposits that have risen to the surface as the salt is less dense than the overlying sediments. The result is a spectacular scene of geological chaos found nowhere else in the world.  It took a lot of work and a little luck for me, an American pilot to get permission to fly my own aircraft in the Islamic Republic, but fortune favors the bold.  From #DesertAirBook, autographed copies available via link in IG bio.
